metadata.case_name: Amalgamated Coalfields Ltd. & Ors. v. Janapada Sabha, Chhindwara

facts.text: Appellants are colliery companies holding mining leases under Government of Madhya Pradesh for extraction of coal from collieries in Chhindwara District.

Respondent Janapada Sabha, Chhindwara, successor of Independent Mining Local Board, issued notices demanding coal tax on coal manufactured at mines, sold for export by rail or otherwise within jurisdiction.

On March 12, 1935, Mining Board resolved to levy coal tax under section 51 of Central Provinces Local Self-Government Act, 1920; sanctioned by local Government on December 16, 1935, effective January 1, 1936.

Local Government notified rules on December 16, 1935 under section 79(1) clauses xv, xix, xxx; Rule 2: payable by mining lease holders; Rule 3: 3 pies per ton on coal, coal dust or coke manufactured at mines, sold for export by rail or otherwise.
In 1943, words 'coke manufactured at the mines' deleted from Rule 3; rate increased: Dec 22, 1943 to 4 pies, July 29, 1946 to 7 pies, July 19, 1947 to 9 pies per ton.
Act of 1920 repealed in 1948 by Central Provinces and Berar Local Self-Government Act, 1948; Janapada Sabha succeeded Mining Board.

Notices served on Amalgamated Coalfields Ltd. and Pench Valley Coal Co. Ltd. on Aug 23, 1958 for Rs. 21,898.64 np and Rs. 11,838.9 np at 9 pies/ton from Jan 1 to June 30, 1958, including coal despatched outside Madhya Pradesh.
Writ Petition No. 31 of 1959 in Supreme Court challenging 1958 notices dismissed on Feb 10, 1961: Amalgamated Coalfields Ltd. v. Janapada Sabha (1962) 1 SCR 1.
Further notices Sep 13, 1960 and Mar 2, 1961 on Amalgamated and Pench for Rs. 1,16,776.25 np and Rs. 65,261.19 np at 9 pies/ton for half-years 1958-1960.
Writ petitions in MP High Court No. 95/1961 and 213/1961 challenging notices including June 9, 1959 notices for Apr 1, 1951-Dec 31, 1957: Rs. 1,92,144.66 np and Rs. 68,319.36 np for exported coal.
High Court dismissed writs holding barred by res judicata due to 1962 1 SCR 1; special leave granted Apr 23, 1962 leading to CA 469,470/1962; Writs 70,71/1962 in SC.

Other appeals from High Court dismissals of writs by Central Provinces Syndicate P Ltd (CA 506: arrears Apr1,1951-Jun30,1959 Rs.20,776.88 np), Kanhan Valley Coal Co. Pvt Ltd (CA 507: Rs.10,970/- same period), Newton Chickli Collieries & Ors (CA 529-534).
Rule 3 deleted by notification Sep 6, 1943 published Sep 10, 1943.
From ~1952, respondent did not collect tax on coal exported outside MP per state advice; after HC judgment Aug 6, 1958 in Newton Chickli writ No.265/1957, resumed.
Assessments already made for periods without including exported coal; notices seek to reopen by adding tax on exported coal.

legal_issues.text: Whether the doctrine of res judicata applies to writ petitions under Art. 32 or 226 challenging tax notices for different periods than previously litigated.
Whether the levy of coal tax under the Act and Rules violates Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution.
Whether increase in tax rate from 3 pies to 9 pies per ton requires previous sanction of Provincial Government under s.51(2) of the 1920 Act.
Whether respondent can reopen completed assessments to demand additional tax on exported coal under the Rules.

petitioner_arguments.text: Res judicata does not apply to writ petitions under Art.32/226 for different tax periods; cause of action distinct each year.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Pandit M.S.M. Sharma v. Dr. Shree Krishna Sinha (1961)1 SCR 96; Daryao v. State of UP (1962)1 SCR 574; English cases like Society of Medical Officers of Health v. Hope

petitioner_arguments.text: Tax levy arbitrary, unreasonable, violates Art.19(1)(f).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. State of Kerala (1961)3 SCR 77

petitioner_arguments.text: Rule 3 prescribes maximum 3 pies/ton; higher rates invalid.
'First imposition' under s.51(2) includes rate increases requiring previous sanction; no sanction for 4,7,9 pies.
Cannot reopen final assessments under Rule 10.

respondent_arguments.text: Challenge barred by res judicata due to prior SC decision in Amalgamated Coalfields (1962)1 SCR 1.
'First imposition' under s.51(2) means only initial levy, not rate increases.

court_reasoning.text: General res judicata applies to Art.32/226 writs, but not constructive res judicata for different periods; decisions on tax liability for one year do not bar subsequent years; distinguished prior case as different grounds.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decision for one year does not operate as res judicata for subsequent year; constructive res judicata not applicable to writs.

court_reasoning.text: Tax levy not violative of Art.19(1)(f); Rules provide quasi-judicial assessment with objections; unlike Moopil Nair.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of Rules provides ample opportunity to object; not capricious.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 3 deleted in 1943; but s.51(2) 'first imposition' includes rate increases requiring previous sanction; no sanction for increases to 4,7,9 pies; notifications by Board itself, not Government.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Imposition at altered rates deemed 'first imposition'; respondent entitled only to 3 pies.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 10 makes assessments final; no provision to reopen; cannot demand additional tax on exported coal for past periods.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finality under Rule 10 binds respondent too.

holdings.text: Doctrine of res judicata (including constructive) does not bar challenge to notices for different periods.
Coal tax levy does not violate Art.19(1)(f).
Rate increases to 9 pies invalid without s.51(2) sanction; valid only at 3 pies.
Reopening of final assessments under Rule 10 not permitted.

precedents_cited.relevance: Prior decision upholding initial notices; but different grounds and periods here.

precedents_cited.relevance: Validated 1949 amendment saving continuance of tax.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pandit M.S.M. Sharma v. Dr. Shree Krishna Sinha
precedents_cited.relevance: Res judicata applies to Art.32 petitions.
High Court writ dismissal on merits bars subsequent writ.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. State of Kerala
precedents_cited.relevance: Levy not confiscatory or arbitrary like there.

precedents_cited.case_name: Society of Medical Officers of Health v. Hope
precedents_cited.relevance: Res judicata generally not for tax assessments different years.

precedents_cited.case_name: Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. v. Municipal Council
precedents_cited.relevance: No res judicata for different valuation year.
Estoppel where point fundamental and conceded.

statutes_cited.relevance: Power to impose tax; rules for assessment; first imposition needs sanction.

Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights; writ jurisdiction; binding precedents; continuance of taxes.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Validity of pre-1935 laws; conditions for tax continuance.

outcome.summary: Appeals and writ petitions allowed; respondent restrained from recovering coal tax higher than 3 pies per ton and from recovering additional tax for years already assessed.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of notices demanding tax at 9 pies/ton and reopening past assessments; limited to 3 pies/ton.

key_quotes.text: the decision of those questions should be treated as collateral or incidental to what is the only issue that is truly submitted to determination.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: On why res judicata does not apply to tax for different years (citing Lord Radcliffe).

key_quotes.text: if the rates are increased and levy is sought to be imposed on the altered rates, the imposition of the levy at these altered rates should be deemed to be included in the expression 'first imposition' under s.51(2).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets s.51(2) to require sanction for rate increases.

key_quotes.text: the finality provided for by Rule 10 will work as much against the respondent as against the assessees.
key_quotes.speaker: court
